_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Farm Product Raw Material Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Program - Data Elements

Simplot Grower Solutions



Executive Summary



For further information concerning this executive summary or other elements of the Risk Management Program, please contact Unit Supervisor, Mike Lemmons at:



Simplot Grower Solutions

19421 Creek Road

Bakersfield CA 93314

Phone: 661-303-6903



POLICY AND GUIDELINES



It is the policy of the J.R. Simplot Company (Policy Statement EN 01.1) to manufacture, handle, store, and dispose of all substances safely and in compliance with the requirements of federal, state, and local environmental laws, while reducing the risks to human health, safety and the environment.  Each manager/supervisor is expected to responsibly implement this policy, and each employee is expected to comply fully with the spirit, as well as the letter of this policy.  The Company will assure that the environmental, health and safety laws, regulations, and standards applicable to its products and operations are known and obeyed by employees.



The J.R. Simplot Company Guideline (Guideline Statement SA 01.2) states that the Company is committed to reducing incidents or occurrences in the workplace that result in human injury, illness, or death, and/or destruction or loss to the Corporation's assets, and to be in compliance with all laws and regulations governing workplace safety.  It is therefore our intent to provide a safe work environment and to protect the Corporation's assets.  This guideline applies to all groups and separate operating entities of the J.R. Simplot Company.  Emergency plans shall be developed for each operating unit outlining the practices and procedures for emergency medical care, fire response, evacuation, or other emergencies.  Each group shall develop and implement appropriate programs for initial and ongoing safety and loss prevention training of employees.



REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The substance that is routinely stored at this facility at or above its RMP threshold quantity is

Anhydrous Ammonia.  Anhydrous Ammonia is received, stored, distributed to area customers as a source of land-applied nitrogen fertilizer, and used as a raw material in the 10-34-0 process.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PROGRAM



This Anhydrous Ammonia facility implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements of the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia", as published by the American National Standard Institute, Inc. (ANSI K61.1); standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia"; and standards of California OSHA (CalOSHA), 8 CCR Sections 500-515, "Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders - Anhydrous Ammonia".



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



In the past five years, there have been no accidental emergency releases of anhydrous ammonia at this site.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This facility has developed a written site-specific emergency response plan and an emergency contingency plan (Integrated Contingency Plan).  The plans address the regulations concerning emergency plans as mandated under:  OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38, 1910.119, & 1910.120; EPA 40 CFR part 264 subpart D, part 265 subpart D, part 68 and 279.52; DOT/RSPAFRP 49 CFR part 194; and California Health & Safety Code section 25503 of Division 6.95.  Elements within this plan include employee training, SARA Title III reporting requirements and community right-to-know, pre-emergency planning, and emergency response planning.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Safety and environmental programs are very dynamic, and since this is an ongoing process, changes toward improvements are evaluated and implemented periodically.  The need for improvement is identified by facility employee inputs, inspections, and audits, which are performed on a regular basis.
